p: B. thuringiensis produces three classes of larvicidal proteins: Cry (exert intoxication through toxin activation, receptor binding, and pore formation in a suitable larval gut environment), Cyt (cytolytic toxicity) when sporulating (parasporal crystals), and Vip proteins throughout the vegetative phase (ionic, non-ionic detergents and pore-forming mechanisms of action were suggested), some of which are toxic against a wide range of insect orders, nematodes, and human-cancer cells. This has been widely employed as an effective biopesticide to control pests that are harmful to crops, forests, and humans. Cyt toxins possess less toxicity against mosquito larvae than Cry toxins [ 126, 127].
